content.description: Start left off of the highest boulder on south side of the Monk. Aid past 4 bolts to a slightly awkward transition to a couple easy free moves. Clip a bolt, then another free move gets you to a bolt ladder (about 8 bolts) through an awesome big roof. At the lip of the roof free climb up and right on hollow sounding jugs to two big eyebolts. From these it is about 25 m back to the belay platform. Fun route.
content.protection: Quickdraws. As of summer 2017, the route is fully equipped. A hand sized cam and a large nut or two can be used for an anchor at the base for roped soloing.
content.location: South side of the Monk. See approach under the Praying Monk area page. The approach requires a 4th/easy 5th class scramble up the headwall.

content.description: Supposedly a scary death route on the northwest face of the Monk. Phoenix Rock mentions the route but really gives no useful info or topo. From looking at the route it would seem the A4 rating might be by old wave standards.
content.location: NW side of the Monk, following the obvious left leaning crack. Fixed ring angle is visible several meters up.

content.description:
Short sport route near the NE arete, first line you see when making the standard approach to the monk. After b1 face some steep opening moves, and continue up the steep face and eventually pull the buldge.

 Hold right above second bolt seems reinforced, and lots of dirt comes off the footholds as you climb. Most of the hands seem solid, but it's camelback and i wouldn't be surprised if some just pooped off.

 Please let me know if anybody knows the name or more info.
content.protection: Well bolted, if the rock holds. 5 bolts to chain anchor, currently has a few fixed draws and stuff.
content.location: When approaching the monk, this is the obvious first sport line you see.

content.description: Start on left trending foot ledge clipping a few bolts to a corner. Go around corner and up to anchors. Surprisingly good rock and some fun moves. Karabin has it listed at 10b but I felt it to be easier!
content.protection: 7 bolts and 2 bolts with a single quick link.
content.location: Walk past start to east face and up through a big keyhole and the route is on the left of the looming face and roof on the south face of Monk! First bolt is a little off center of the wall, down low ish!

content.description: First find a large Boulder that makes a small cave on Southeast side of The Monk. Climb bolted face up and and to the right around corner to access the East face.
content.protection: 9 bolts to top. The top has several thick metal rings directly on the rock.  You can use two as a top belay anchor but they'll be one above another not side by side.  Belaying up a second can be a bit uncomfortable to get below the anchors.  Rappelling back down the route requires a 70m rope.  You can rappel off the south face with a 60m rope (90 degrees left of the way you came up).
content.location: The monk is the tower that is above the headwall, you cant miss it, route is on the east side.

content.description:
The Praying Monk has probably been climbed by more Phoenix beginners than any other formation in central Arizona, although the advent of gyms and sport climbing has lessened this absolute somewhat over the last ten years. The East Face route, first climbed in 1951 by Phoenix pioneer climber and ex-mayor, Gary Driggs, is the usual route of ascent. 

  If you wonder how the Monk got it's name, climb it late some sunny afternoon, and look down to the east to see the "praying monks" shadow.
